comments:
Wayne" <wayne@workingobjects.com> wrote in message 
news:a1g0ad$foe$1@rogue.oti.com...
> I frequently encounter timeout exceptions when debugging Java programs in
> the 20011219 release. I'm using Sun's JDK1.3.1 on Win2K. The problem usually
> arises when inspecting params or variables while stepping the debugger
> through code. When returning from inspecting to stepping through code I get
> this error message: "org.eclipse.jdi.TimeoutException occured creating step
> request."

I reported this problem on the newsgroup. After reinstalling Eclipse w/ 
JDK1.4.0b3. The problem appears to have disappeared (fingers crossed).

Wayne
Closing.
Will reopen if needed.
I get these timeout exceptions occuring all the time.

Created an attachment (id=2113)
java version

What version of Eclipse are you using? What is the timeout value set in your 
debug preferences? (Window -> Preferences -> Java -> Debug -> Debugger 
timeout). Does the problem occurr with JDK 1.4.1:

java version "1.4.1-beta"
Java(TM) 2 Runtime Environment, Standard Edition (build 1.4.1-beta-b11)
Java HotSpot(TM) Client VM (build 1.4.1-beta-b11, mixed mode)

I took heed of and implemented everything you advised Darin. As far as the 
version of Eclipse goes, I'm not too sure how to find that out, but I downloaded  
the file <eclipse-SDK-2_0_1-win32.zip>.

One thing that may be the cause of my problem is interacting with the Swing 
application whilst stepping thru code. Specifically, when the application got to 
its first breakpoint I would minimise it. I am now interacting with eclipse 
straight away (ie./ while eclipse has control, don't touch the gui), and have 
thus far not experienced any TimeoutExceptions. Will post here if I get any 
more.

For some days now I'm using Eclipse 2.0.2, and I have the (subjective)
impression, that the timeout exception while stepping through the code (when
debugging) happens much more than in 2.0.1 (and there it already appeared much
too often).
As far as I could see, the timeout values have no effect on how often the error
appears but only on how long you have to wait until the message box showing the
error appears.

My JVM:
java version "1.4.1"
Java(TM) 2 Runtime Environment, Standard Edition (build 1.4.1-b21)
Java HotSpot(TM) Client VM (build 1.4.1-b21, mixed mode)

My debugger timeout: 20000ms

My Eclipse: V2.0.2, Buildid 200211071448 (Linux GTK)

Martin, we do not see these timeout exceptions. Can you supply us with an 
example program that exhibits this behavior? Are you doing remote debugging or 
local debugging? What type of applications are you debugging (i.e. what sort of 
launch configurations)?
Adding Martin as CC to "see" previous comment.

With 2.0.2 I only did local debugging so far. With 2.0.1 I often did remote 
debugging and there I had the impression that this Timeout prob occurs much 
more often than in local debugging.
Anyway, I will try to provide you a test program reproducing the prob, but it 
may take some days.

BTW: Does the VM memory setting (when starting the debuggee program) have any 
influence on the frequency the Timeout prob occurs? In 2.0.1 I had the 
impression that increasing the VM memory causes the Timeout to occur less 
often (but it only was subjective impression...)

Sorry, but I cannot provide you a test case demonstrating the bug since it 
seems that it has to be due to the combination Eclipse/JDK/Operating 
System/perhaps machine. My problematic program doesn't cause an Eclipse 2.0.2 
with JDK 1.4.1 on Windows XP to get that timeout prob, and so it doesn't on a 
different Linux machine, too. 
Nevertheless, I will keep an eye on it, and if I'm able to reproduce it on any 
other machine than mine (before you fixed it), I will attach the program to 
this bug.
Marking as "works for me" (for now).

Hi all,

I am afraid this is still open.

java version "1.3.1_06"
Java(TM) 2 Runtime Environment, Standard Edition (build 1.3.1_06-b01)
Java HotSpot(TM) Client VM (build 1.3.1_06-b01, mixed mode)

running on win2k

C:\Eclipse\Eclipse210-RC2
Version: 2.1.0
Build id: 200303071024

Machine running low on memory.

Regards, Christoph

resolve it.

The GPF indicates a VM crash. Is this only reproduceable on J9? If so, it 
likely indicates a VM bug that should be filed with the VM vendor.

(re)Marking as dup. Please open a new bug report if problem persists.

*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 16036 ***
